results.justification: The document explicitly states the research methodology, focusing on causal modeling to identify relationships between writing behaviors and essay quality. (Section 3.3)
Sections 3.1-3.4 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, including dataset selection, conceptual model development, causal effect identification, and estimation.
The document states the use of the publicly available CoAuthor dataset and provides a link: 'https://coauthor.stanford.edu/' (Section 3.1)
Data is publicly available, so justification for non-sharing is not applicable.
The document references a detailed description of the dataset in Lee et al. [44] and mentions the inclusion of final outputs and log trace events. (Section 3.1)
Data collection methods are described, detailing the recruitment of writers, writing topics, and the interaction with GPT-3. (Section 3.1)
The document provides a link to a GitHub repository containing the analysis code: 'https://github.com/CarsonYang518/LAK25-GAI-Writing-Causal' (Section 3.4)
Code is publicly available, so justification for non-sharing is not applicable.
The document states that the code for data preparation is included in the shared repository. (Section 3.4)
Statistical tests (X-learner algorithm), models (Directed Acyclic Graph), and assumptions (back-door criterion) are clearly described. (Section 3.3)
Effect sizes (ATE), and p-values are reported in Table 2 and discussed in the results section.
The study is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
The study is primarily quantitative; data coding and analysis are not described in a qualitative manner.
Results are clearly presented in tables (Table 2, Table 3) and discussed in the results section (Section 4.1, 4.2).
Limitations related to the dataset, missing information, and data distribution are discussed in Section 4.3.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
